headline: Trump Administration Maintains It Is Tough on Russia
summary: The Trump administration disputed criticism that it is going easy on Russia, detailing what senior officials described as a year of efforts to counter Moscow’s interference in the U.S. elections and interventions in Ukraine and Syria.

headline: Pennsylvania GOP Ask Supreme Court to Block New Congressional Map
summary: Pennsylvania Republicans filed a new emergency appeal at the U.S. Supreme Court Wednesday in a last-ditch effort to block a new congressional map imposed by the state’s highest court.

headline: A N.J. County Sues Purdue Pharma, Sackler Family for Opioid Marketing
summary: Camden County in southern New Jersey has joined hundreds of counties nationwide in suing the opioid-painkiller manufacturer Purdue Pharma, but in an unusual step it also named members of the company’s controlling family, the Sacklers.

headline: SEC Calls For Curbs On Employee Trading During Cyberbreaches
summary: The SEC issued new guidelines on cybersecurity disclosures for public companies, including suggestions for adjusting insider trading policies to account for investigations into cyber breaches.

headline: High Court: Guilty Plea Doesn’t Prohibit Constitutional Challenge to Convictions
summary: The Supreme Court held that defendants who plead guilty retain the right to challenge their convictions as unconstitutional, frustrating prosecutors who said the rule would inject uncertainty into a criminal justice system built on plea bargains.

headline: Toys ‘R’ Us Plans to Close Another 200 Stores
summary: Toys “R” Us Inc. plans to close another 200 stores and lay off a significant portion of its corporate staff following a disappointing holiday sales season, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Mueller Examines Manafort Loans
summary: Special counsel Robert Mueller and federal prosecutors are examining as much as $16 million in loans that a bank run by a former campaign adviser to President Trump made to former campaign chairman Paul Manafort.

headline: Thomas vs. Sotomayor
summary: A Supreme Court exchange illuminates judicial differences.

headline: Billy Graham
summary: A North Carolina farm boy brought the Gospel to the world.

headline: Iran’s Syrian Front
summary: Assad’s atrocities grow as Tehran builds a new anti-Israel satellite.

headline: A West Point Welcome
summary: Cadet Peter Wang takes his place on the Long Gray Line.

headline: Tops Markets Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection
summary: Supermarket chain Tops Markets LLC filed for bankruptcy protection Wednesday, the latest regional grocery chain to look to restructure its balance sheet as consumers move to nontraditional food retailers.

headline: Boko Haram Kidnaps More Schoolgirls in Nigeria
summary: A mass kidnapping at a boarding school in northeastern Nigeria this week has raised fears of a repeat of the 2014 abduction of students in Chibok.

headline: Commerce Secretary Becomes Point Man For Commercial Space Projects
summary: Responding to industry complaints that federal rules increasingly hamper private ventures in space, Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross has emerged as the deregulation czar of the heavens.

headline: YouTube Says It Mistakenly Promoted a Conspiratorial Video on Florida Shooting
summary: Google’s video site and other social media struggle to suppress misleading and false content on their platforms.

headline: Merger Creates Regional Hospital Giant
summary: Two large nonprofit hospital systems—Bon Secours Health System Inc. of Marriottsville, Md., and Mercy Health, headquartered in Cincinnati, have announced plans to merge, in another example of hospitals bulking as the battle for patients grows increasingly fierce.

headline: Supreme Court Limits Suits Against Foreign Terror Sponsors
summary: The Supreme Court blocked victims of Iranian-backed terrorism from seizing Persian antiquities on loan to a U.S. university, holding that Tehran’s property is protected by a federal law that immunizes foreign governments from most lawsuits.

headline: Review: Showdown in the Levant
summary: Had the Crusaders conquered Damascus, Cairo or Aleppo, they might have established a permanent presence in the Middle East. Christopher Tyerman reviews ‘The Field of Blood’ by Nicholas Morton.

headline: America’s Security Depends on Mexico
summary: Working together to stop drug cartels and illegal immigration.

headline: Billy Graham Bore Witness for 99 Years
summary: He was perhaps the most significant evangelist since the Apostle Paul.

headline: Trump Wastes Another Weekend
summary: The indictment was a perfect time to pivot. Instead he amplified the media noise.

headline: The FBI’s Parkland Fail
summary: The list of fatal mistakes by federal agencies in recent years is staggering.

headline: Ford North America President Leaves Following Misconduct Allegations
summary: Raj Nair, a top Ford executive, has been fired following misconduct allegations, the latest high-ranking leader to be shown the door amid broader scrutiny of workplace behavior in corporate America.

headline: Why America Is Going Broke
summary: Entitlements are driving deficits and debt. Absent reform, the problem will soon become a crisis.

headline: Both Sides of the Aisle Want Better Roads and Ports
summary: Conservative Republicans and progressive Democrats can find common ground on infrastructure.

headline: Notable & Quotable: Russia
summary: ‘In a society with a strong sense of shared reality, a bunch of subliterate tweets and ridiculous ads would be nothing but a curiosity.’

headline: Cape Town May Dry Up Because of an Aversion to Israel
summary: The Palestinian Authority accepts the Jewish state’s help on water projects. South Africa refuses it.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for edition of Feb. 22, 2018

headline: A Question for U.K. Ministers: What Were You After With Brexit?
summary: After a week of speechifying by various members of the British cabinet, it is easier to identify what the government wants to stay the same after leaving the EU than what it wants to change, Simon Nixon writes.

headline: U.S. Dollar Rallies
summary: The U.S. dollar rose for a fourth consecutive day Wednesday after a release of the minutes of the Fed’s January meeting showed central bankers are concerned about a quickening of inflation.

headline: Roku Shares Plunge On Weak Forecast
summary: Shares of Roku Inc. plunged nearly 21% during extended trading Wednesday after the maker of streaming-media devices forecast a steeper-than-expected loss this year.

headline: Venezuela Opposition to Boycott Vote
summary: Venezuela’s largest opposition parties said they would boycott the April 22 presidential elections, casting further doubt on the legitimacy of the vote in which leftist leader Nicolás Maduro is seeking a second, six-year term.

headline: GE Won’t Sell Baker Hughes Stake Yet, Lowers 2018 Profit View
summary: GE lowered its 2018 profit outlook and said it has no intention of selling down its majority stake in oil services firm Baker Hughes before 2019, a shift from its previous exploration of exiting the business.

headline: Dish Network Gains Sling TV Customers but Retention Is a Problem
summary: Dish Network Corp. said its Sling TV streaming-video service has signed up 2.2 million subscribers in the company’s first disclosure of a figure, but Chairman Charlie Ergen said customer retention is a significant challenge.

headline: Photos of the Day: Feb. 21
summary: In photos selected by Wall Street Journal editors on Wednesday, Indian Muslim women hold placards with messages against a divorce bill, people walk through snow in Switzerland, protesters rally against gun violence in Florida, and more.

headline: 10 New York City Tow-Truck Firms Indicted
summary: Manhattan prosecutors accused 17 people and 10 companies of using fraud and violence to create an illegal monopoly within New York City’s towing industry.

headline: Oil Prices Mixed Ahead of Inventory Forecast
summary: Oil prices were mixed as the U.S. dollar rallied and investors anticipated data expected to show another increase in U.S. crude output.

headline: The Pleasant Surprises of a Renewed Utah Symphony
summary: Thierry Fischer, music director of the Utah Symphony, likes to juxtapose music one doesn’t expect to hear on the same program, like a bill shared by Saint-Saëns and Bernstein.

headline: In a Fresh Sign of Strength, Glencore Quadruples Earnings
summary: Glencore said it quadrupled its earnings in 2017, increased its dividend payout to investors and was on the lookout for deals—fresh signs of strength in the global mining industry.

headline: ‘Extralife’ by Darlingside Review: Folk Meets A Cappella
summary: The quartet blazes its own trail on its third album, filled with rounded tones and harmonic motion.

headline: U.S. Government Bonds Fall After Fed Minutes
summary: U.S. government bond prices slid Wednesday, sending yields to fresh multiyear highs, after minutes from the Federal Reserve’s latest meeting struck some investors as being more hawkish than they had expected.

headline: U.S. Moves to Halt Turkey’s Drift Toward Iran and Russia
summary: The Trump administration has embarked on a new campaign to try to repair bilateral ties and pull Ankara out of its deepening alliances with Tehran and Moscow but Washington is struggling to find a way to address Turkey’s chief grievance.

headline: Gold Prices Maintain Gains After Fed Minutes
summary: None

headline: The CNN Situation
summary: Blitzer commands a rhetorical attack on the President.

headline: Hawaiian Dumps Airbus Order for Boeing Jets
summary: Hawaiian Airlines is expected to cancel an order for Airbus SE long-haul jets in favor of buying its first new Boeing Co. 787-9 Dreamliners, according to people familiar with the negotiations.

headline: Former Netanyahu Aide to Testify in Corruption Case
summary: A confidant of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has turned state witness for the Israeli police and will testify in a corruption probe, a person familiar with the matter said Wednesday, the latest twist in a series of cases that threaten to bring down Israel’s leader.

headline: Broadcom Cuts Offer for Qualcomm Over New NXP Deal Price
summary: Broadcom knocked more than $4 billion off its bid to acquire Qualcomm, firing back a day after Qualcomm sweetened its own offer to acquire NXP Semiconductors by billions.

headline: Contractor Winds Down Work on Puerto Rico Grid as Restoration Continues
summary: Fluor Corp.’s work rebuilding Puerto Rico’s hurricane-damaged power gridis winding down. Some 15 of the island still doesn’t have power.

headline: JPMorgan Chase to Build New Midtown NYC Headquarters
summary: The new building will replace the firm’s current headquarters at the same address

headline: Funding Snapshot: Cybersecurity Startup Dover Microsystems Picks Up $6 Million Seed Round
summary: Company: Dover Microsystems Inc.

headline: Activist Investor Calls for Spinoff of Some Bloomin’ Brands Restaurants
summary: An activist investor is calling for Bloomin’ Brands to spin off some of its restaurant brands, revamp its board of directors and adopt more aggressive cost-cutting goals, arguing the Outback Steakhouse-operator is lagging behind its industry peers.

headline: France Proposes Tougher Law on Migrants
summary: France’s government presented a bill to toughen immigration and asylum laws by doubling the time migrants can be detained, strengthening police powers to search them, and shortening the time migrants have to appeal rejected asylum claims.

headline: South Africa’s New Budget Aims to Repair Zuma’s Economic Damage
summary: President Cyril Ramaphosa faced his first major test as his government presented a budget that seeks to repair the economic damage wrought under his predecessor while reassuring international investors and South Africa’s poor black majority.

headline: Trump Economic Report Blames Obama Policies for Slow Growth
summary: President Donald Trump’s first official economic report to Congress makes a lengthy case that the U.S. economy has been weak in recent years, not because of the severity of the most recent recession, but because of policy mistakes by Mr. Trump’s predecessor.

headline: Tough Start for Housing
summary: Homes sales slowed in January even before higher rates and the tax law hit the market.

headline: Home Sales Post Their Sharpest Drop in Three Years
summary: Sales of previously owned U.S. homes in January experienced their sharpest annual drop in more than three years as low inventories and rising prices and interest rates took a toll.

headline: Interior Department’s Drone Army Fights Fires and Monitors Wildlife
summary: The Interior Department is dramatically amplifying its use of drones, launching thousands of unmanned flights to help manage the nation’s public lands, and creating the largest federal drone program outside of the Pentagon, federal officials said.

headline: Supreme Court Curbs Protections for Whistleblowers
summary: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that individuals must report alleged corporate wrongdoing to the Securities and Exchange Commission, not just to their companies, to qualify for whistleblower protections under the Dodd-Frank Act.

headline: A Dessert That Never Fails to Comfort: Tres Leches Cake
summary: A cake drenched in milk, rum, coffee and coconut provides a poignant taste of Puerto Rico for a writer and her family. The recipe’s simple, widely accessible ingredients make it easy to recreate anywhere.

headline: Treasury Recommends Keeping Dodd-Frank Liquidation Power
summary: The Trump administration recommended retaining the government’s power to seize and unwind a failing financial firm in a crisis, endorsing a plank of the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial law.

headline: Stopping School Shootings and Mass Murder
summary: We need enhanced background checks on the sale of firearms, bans on military-style assault weapons and bump stocks and limitations on the size of ammo magazines.

headline: Profile: On Working With Single, High-Income Women
summary: Adviser Profile: Nancy Coutu, co-founder of Money Managers Financial Group, finds that many female clients “simply connect better” with female advisers given their unique planning needs and investing mindset.

headline: FDIC Sues 16 Banks as Receiver for Failed Puerto Rico Bank
summary: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. sued 16 banks connected to the Libor rigging scandal as part of its effort to recover funds related to Doral Bank, a Puerto Rican institution that collapsed in 2015.

headline: Religious, Political Leaders React to Graham’s Death
summary: Religious and political leaders from across the country expressed admiration and respect for evangelist Billy Graham, who died Wednesday at his North Carolina home.

headline: Congress Should Make Rural Broadband a High Priority
summary: The widening digital divide is a national crisis deserving of a national response. A federal grant and loan package—using funding from the Bipartisan Budget Agreement—is necessary to stop the rural decline and connect rural America.

headline: Want to Ski Norway’s Beautiful Senja Island? You’ll Have to Climb it First
summary: Gloriously off-the-grid, this mountainous island offers miles of pristine, powder-rich runs. But to ski them, you need to climb them.

headline: GOP Congressman in Colorado Gets an Earful About Guns
summary: A GOP lawmaker in a Colorado swing district faced criticism from his constituents Tuesday about gun policies, illustrating the tricky landscape for some Republicans heading into the midterm elections.

headline: Lloyds: An Undervalued Cash Cow in Banking
summary: Lloyds Banking Group has become nice little earner for investors, as the U.K. bank launched a share buyback and promises more.

headline: The Quest for Unconsciousness: A Brief History of Anesthesia
summary: The ancient Greeks used alcohol and opium. Patients in the 12th century got a ‘soporific sponge.’ A look at anesthetics over the centuries.

headline: Vox Media Cuts 50 Employees, Scales Back on Social Video
summary: Vox Media is cutting 5% of staff as industry changes, like Facebook’s adjustment to its news feed, makes it harder to make money from social video.

summary: Kym Gold, the co-founder of True Religion jeans, designed this Encino compound with an orchard and vegetable garden

summary: The fight in Afrin has thrown a spotlight on international powers—from Turkey and Russia to Iran and the U.S.—vying for position in Syria. Here’s a rundown of what’s at stake for the competing powers.

summary: The Rev. Billy Graham, who died Wednesday, built evangelicalism into a force that rivaled liberal Protestantism and Roman Catholicism in the U.S. His leadership summits and crusades in more than 185 countries and territories forged powerful global links among conservative Christians.

headline: Are Six Ovens Enough?
summary: Inside some kitchens equipped with ovens that bake, broil, steam, spin, microwave and warm; set-ups designed for chefs and catering teams.

summary: To encourage people to speak up about sexual-misconduct allegations at work, some companies are experimenting with apps designed to make reporting easier.

summary: Slow lending growth can be a sign of nervousness, but this year it is tied to positives like the tax cut and will likely pick up in the coming months.

summary: The University of Pennsylvania is No. 1 in the area in the WSJ/THE College Rankings.

headline: Priceline Group Rebrands to Booking Holdings
summary: Priceline Group has changed its name to Booking Holdings, a move the company says better represents the diversity of its businesses.

headline: Amenities War Breaks Out in Long Island City Rentals
summary: A swelling supply of apartments is forcing some Long Island City luxury developers to trim rents and agree to other concessions, even as they roll out upgraded finishes and a smorgasbord of amenities from swimming pools to game rooms.

summary: The new CBS sitcom “Living Biblically” attempts to wring some laughs out of religion while also treating it with respect.

summary: Here's your morning roundup of the biggest marketing, advertising and media industry news and happenings.

headline: Here’s a Change: U.S. Borrowing Costs Among Highest in Developed World
summary: As if there weren’t enough evidence that the ground is shifting in markets, here’s something that hasn’t happened in nearly two decades: America is paying more to borrow than Australia.

headline: I Avoided the Norovirus, but I Caught the Curling Bug
summary: When the Olympics are over, our Seoul bureau chief will go back to writing about North Korea. But until then, you can find him at the Gangneung Curling Center.

headline: Glencore Rewards Those Who Wait
summary: Glencore is riding high, lifted by a wave of economic optimism and high expectations for an electric-powered future. But high leverage remains a vulnerability.

headline: The 10-Point: Gerard Baker on rising Treasury yields, Walmart’s struggles and more
summary: A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.

headline: When Ford Warned People to Stop Driving Some of Its Trucks, a Regulator Lost Sleep
summary: Ford’s decision to instruct tens of thousands of truck owners to stop driving vehicles with potentially lethal air bags raises fresh concerns for regulators already grappling with the largest automotive safety recall in U.S. history.

headline: In Figure Skating, Russia’s (Perfectly Legal) Secret Sauce
summary: Alina Zagitova and Evgenia Medvedeva backloaded their short programs to break a scoring record. While it’s perfectly within the rules, it has been a flashpoint for discussion this season.

headline: Florida Considers Death Penalty in School Shooting
summary: Defense lawyers seeking to spare Nikolas Cruz execution for last week’s school shooting, could face a high hurdle: Florida’s historic embrace of the death penalty, which has led to the second-largest death row in the U.S.

headline: Folgers Wakes Up With a New Premium Cup of Coffee
summary: Folgers is taking its biggest risk in decades with a new brand aimed at reviving the 167-year-old coffee giant, the latest food maker to try to win over younger consumers.

headline: What to Watch in the Fed Minutes
summary: The Federal Reserve on Wednesday will offer more details on policy makers’ outlook for 2018 when it releases the minutes of their Jan. 30-31 meeting. Officials voted then to hold their benchmark federal-funds rate steady in a range between 1.25% and 1.5%. The minutes will be released at 2 p.m. EST.

headline: Lawsuit Alleges MetLife Mistake Helped a Woman Keep Settlement Money From Her Daughter
summary: A lawsuit related to medical malpractice is the latest example of an unexpected problem popping up at MetLife from decades-old business.

headline: Deal Making Gets Tougher for Generic Drugmakers
summary: Generic drug M&A would seem logical, but a new policy at the FTC complicates matters.

headline: U.S. Colleges Are Separating Into Winners and Losers
summary: For generations, a swelling population of college-age students, rising enrollment rates and generous student loans helped all schools, even mediocre ones, to flourish. Those days are ending.

headline: Lotte Group Chairman Resigns From Its Japanese Holding Company
summary: Shin Dong-bin’s resignation could reignite an ugly family dispute with his older brother over control of South Korea’s fifth-largest conglomerate. Lotte operates businesses ranging from chemicals to snacks, supermarkets, entertainment and hotels.

headline: Johnny Weir Absolutely Loves the Word Absolutely
summary: We decided to rewatch NBC’s Olympics figure-skating broadcast to analyze the analyst and break down the words that make Johnny Weir a uniquely ebullient broadcaster.

headline: Alina Zagitova Takes Lead Over Evgenia Medvedeva in Women’s Short Program
summary: Alina Zagitova smashed a record score set barely 20 minutes earlier by her compatriot Evgenia Medvedeva to lead after the women’s short program.

headline: Photos: Women’s Downhill Skiing at the Pyeongchang Olympics
summary: Italy's Sofia Goggia won downhill gold and Norway’s Ragnhild Mowinckel took silver, while American Lindsey Vonn—who missed the last Olympics with an injury—finished third to became the oldest female Alpine skier to medal.

headline: Italy’s Sofia Goggia Wins the Downhill; Lindsey Vonn Takes Bronze
summary: American Lindsey Vonn won a bronze medal in the downhill on Wednesday, sealing her comeback in her best event after missing the 2014 Olympics with an injury. Italy’s Sofia Goggia won gold.

headline: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: Trump, at White House Forum, Signals Support for Arming School Staff
summary: President Donald Trump, leading an emotional discussion with families touched by school gun violence, signaled support for a plan to arm teachers and coaches and also tighten background checks and mental-health screening before gun purchases.

headline: Trump Again Presses Sessions Over Russia Probe
summary: President Trump renewed his public pressure on Attorney General Jeff Sessions, suggesting the Justice Department should be looking at the Obama administration as part of its Russia probe.

headline: Saudi Arabia Stymies U.S. Over Pakistan Terror List
summary: Saudi Arabia joined Turkey and China in a move to block a U.S.-led attempt this week to place Pakistan on an international terror-financing watch list, according to officials involved in the process, in a rare disagreement between Riyadh and the Trump administration.

headline: JPMorgan Chase to Build Giant New Headquarters in Manhattan
summary: JPMorgan Chase plans to build new headquarters in New York City, the first major project under a city rezoning plan designed to rejuvenate one of its biggest job centers.

headline: Amazon Is Taking Over the Stock Market, Too
summary: Three technology titans have powered nearly half of the S&P 500’s advance this year, a worrying sign for investors expecting a strengthening economy to lift shares of manufacturers, oil companies and other firms whose fortunes typically improve with growth.

headline: Twitter Faces Conservatives’ Ire After Moves to Curb Automated Accounts
summary: Twitter banned some kinds of automated accounts and placed restrictions on posting simultaneously from multiple accounts, curbs that drew complaints from conservative members who claim they are being unfairly targeted.

headline: U.S. Stocks End Lower After Fed Minutes
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average gave up its gains and swung 475 points as concerns about higher interest rates resurfaced following the release of minutes from the Federal Reserve’s January meeting.

headline: Parkland Students Protest, Raising Political Pressure for Tougher Gun Laws
summary: High-school students who survived Florida’s deadly school shooting last week descended on the state capital Wednesday to plead for stricter gun-control measures, raising pressure on lawmakers in the normally firearm-friendly state to pass legislation.

headline: SpaceX Indicates Internet System Will Take Longer Than Anticipated
summary: SpaceX’s proposed internet-via-space project is slated to launch two experimental satellites on Thursday, even as the company tamps down expectations such prototypes will quickly evolve into a functioning global system.

headline: Why an American Airlines Monopoly Works for Charlotte
summary: In contrast to many cities luring low-cost competitors to their airports, Charlotte, N.C., has stuck with a dominant carrier, accepting high prices in exchange for plentiful flights.

headline: R-Rated Behavior of Star Producer Is a Drama for Disney
summary: Tom Schumacher, the executive behind Disney’s new “Frozen” musical, has been accused of explicit sexual language and behavior in the workplace, even as he turned the entertainment company into a powerful force on Broadway.

headline: Big Air: Either the Best or Worst Thing for Snowboarding
summary: Big air is easy to understand and visually stunning, but some snowboarders worry about where it could push the sport stylistically, with judges incentivizing an increasingly acrobatic look.

headline: Team USA Falls in Hockey Shootout
summary: Lacking NHL players, the U.S. squad failed to advance after being unable to make any of its five shots in the shootout.

headline: Small Business Thinks Big About Recruiting
summary: To find qualified employees in a tight job market, small and midsize companies are getting creative, reaching out to local high schools, beefing up internships and even offering to pay vacation costs.

headline: Sorry, Collectors, Nobody Wants Your Beanie Babies Anymore
summary: Two decades after the great stuffed-bear craze, speculators are back, hoping someone will finally buy the collectibles.

headline: How Jeffrey Immelt’s ‘Success Theater’ Masked the Rot at GE
summary: A culture that disdained bad news contributed to overoptimistic forecasts and botched strategies. GE stock has almost halved since Mr. Immelt resigned as CEO and the company is considering whether to break itself up.

headline: U.S. Wins Its First-Ever Cross-Country Gold
summary: The U.S. won its first-ever Olympic gold medal in cross-country skiing as Jessie Diggins and Kikkan Randall took the women’s team sprint free event—a sorely needed adrenaline boost for the U.S. Olympic team.

headline: Some Companies Move to Gender-Blind Leave for New Parents
summary: In a few corners of corporate America, companies are discarding parental-leave policies that encode distinctions between mothers and fathers, arguably holding women back at work and relegating men to secondary roles at home. Instead, they are offering gender-blind time off for all new parents.

headline: The Rise of Bitcoin Factories: Mining for the Masses
summary: The surge in bitcoin’s price is luring individuals and corporations to try their hand at mining cryptocurrencies, giving rise to firms offering services that make mining easier for the masses.

headline: Saudi Efforts to Aid War-Torn Yemen Stall
summary: Saudi Arabia and its allies are giving $1.5 billion to their war-ravaged neighbor, but their ability to fix the country’s humanitarian crisis is limited by their status as combatants—and because many aid groups are reluctant to take their money.

headline: Airbnb’s Push Into ‘Experiences’ Has Been a Slog
summary: Airbnb’s Experiences service, where travelers book outings with local experts, has been off to a sluggish start as the company hunts for new revenue sources beyond home rentals.

headline: America’s Emerging Petro Economy Flips the Impact of Oil
summary: The effect of oil prices on the U.S. economy used to be straightforward: Higher was bad. Yet between 2014 and early 2016, as oil collapsed, growth slowed sharply. Since then oil has doubled, yet the economy has accelerated.

headline: The Winter Olympics Are Too Long. Here’s How to Fix Them
summary: Eighteen days of curling. Twelve nights of speedskating. No Winter Games have ever been longer than Pyeongchang. Why a shorter Olympics would be a better Olympics.

headline: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ
summary: Walmart launches an online makeover, retailers in a rush to consolidate and a distribution overhaul fries KFC’s supply chain.

headline: Fed Gives Bullish Signals on Economy
summary: Federal Reserve officials agreed last month that a strengthening economic growth outlook bolstered their plans to keep raising short-term interest rates this year, minutes from their January meeting show.
